added per 100 grams to clarify the nutritional composition statement

/* Etymology */ rmv unsupported "regions of [the United States] with a strong Mexican or Spanish influence": the name "garbanzo bean" is used commonly (alongside "chickpea") even in regions of the US without "strong Mexican or Spanish influence"—that's probably because the whole country (the contiguous states, anyway) has been influenced by Hispanic (especially Mexican) cuisine and culture, even regions with minimal Hispanic population

Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/Kushalraj4841|Kushalraj4841]] identified as test/vandalism using [[WP:STiki|STiki]]

Chana dal is produced by removing the outer layer of kala chana and then by splitting the kernel. It is one of the most popular ingredients in India which has a nutty flavor and the  seeds are high in protein.

/* Leaves */  I took out that paragraph because it clearly doesn't belong in the paragraph about leaves.  It also seems to contradict itself by saying the reason they were malnourished was both because of AND independent of the fact they ate chickpeas

/* Human consumption */Corrections about panelle.. not a batter used to coat vegetables or meat, but one set as a curd and deep fried.  Additions about cecina, a Tuscan variation of farinata and arguably older.
